title: Cheika quits after Wallabies' loss to England
text:
As other first-tier rugby nations such as New Zealand and England continue through to the semi-finals of the World Cup in Japan, Australia's top players will be flying home after a disappointing campaign.

Wallabies coach Michael Cheika and captain Michael Hooper embrace after Australia's loss to England. Getty

Rugby Australia – which has been beset with problems over the past few years, including the sacking of star player Israel Folau – went back to square one, looking for a new coach and trying to lure fans from other popular winter sports such as AFL and rugby league.

While there is no official prize money at the Rugby World Cup, the game's governing body in Australia missed out on the chance to leverage lucrative commercial deals on the back of a good performance at the tournament.

It would also have put them in a stronger position in the next broadcasting rights deal that starts in 2021.

Players, such as captain Michael Hooper and retiring stars David Pocock and Will Genia will also be out of pocket. They stood to receive a bonus $125,000 if they had won the World Cup, or even an extra $25,000 for victory in a semi-final on top of the $10,000 match fee, as part of a $5.5 million prize pool from Rugby Australia.

The success of reaching the World Cup final in England in 2015 is a distant memory for the 2019 Wallabies who were well below the standard of a world class team.

The Australian side was ranked sixth coming into the World Cup and played like it.

Advertisement

The host nation, which has been deprived of playing consistently against tier-one countries, showed the Wallabies how to play the game – fast, skilfully and with determination.

Divisive Wallabies coach Michael Cheika, whose post-game rants about match referees were starting to wear thin, announced his resignation late Sunday. His 50 per cent success rate after five years is not good enough.

Nothing less than victory

Rugby Australia chief executive Raelene Castle said before the World Cup that nothing less than victory would be deemed to be a successful campaign for the Wallabies.

There is no obvious successor to Cheika. New Zealand-born coach Dave Rennie, who is coaching in Glasgow, is the only name being consistently thrown around.

Former Wallabies coach Bob Dwyer, who helped the national team win the 1991 tournament, said coaching was a brutal gig, but the Cheika era should not be seen as a failure after the 2015 finals appearance.

"It's a tricky business coaching. The only thing you can be sure of is you're going to lose your job. I think we can say he's been a successful Wallabies coach," he told The Australian Financial Review.

The early exit of the Wallabies will also add to further anxiety about the precarious state of rugby in Australia as more players chase the high salaries in Europe or Japan.

Advertisement

Rugby Australia recorded a net surplus of $2.8 million in 2018, but its financial future hinges on securing another strong broadcasting deal after the current contract runs out in 2020.

Critics said there is a major disconnect between the international, Super Rugby and club level.b

Sad exit: David Pocock, far right, reacts to defeat with Wallabies teammates. Getty

Former Wallabies forward and now Queensland Investment Corporation chief executive Damien Frawley said rugby will never be able to compete with rugby league and AFL while it does not have a permanent home on free-to-air television, rather than just subscription service Foxtel.

But Dwyer remained up-beat, saying participation in rugby, especially women, is going well.

"Club rugby, which for me is the real barometer, is going from strength to strength," he said.

"Rugby supporters are a different bunch from other football sports. They are quite staunch members of their own fraternity. They don't make much noise or fuss, but they are loyal."

That loyalty will be tested over the next four years.
description: Michael Cheika has quit as Wallabies head coach after the team’s devastating loss to England in the Rugby World Cup quarter finals on Saturday night.
